The thing that kills me the most about the OP2 development community, and the primary thing that keeps me from using it as my DD is the lack of any legitimate kernel development. We had a brief glimmer of hope that AK would work his magic on the device and for a short while he did, however since his departure it's been nothing but crickets.

I mean, at least we've got the likes of Lightning & Nuclear Kernels on OPO carrying on and continuing to improve AK's work on that device. On the OP2's end, not so much.

Beyond that, it's pretty clear that the state of OP2's development community is pretty poor overall, very few "official" ROMs, and even with the unofficial builds do have access to, it basically always boils down to choosing between forks of Grarak's CM and 'debloated' stock ROMs. Not that there's anything wrong with either, and I am thankful for what we do have but there is certainly an evident lack of diversification and overall developer interest. In many ways much of the blame for this falls on OnePlus themselves but it really is a shame because the OP2 is far from a bad device, it's actually a really good device with great potential that isn't being unlocked because it's been shackled with sh*tty software that no one wants to work with and/or is not being provided the tools needed to work with it. 

I think a lot of this ultimately comes down to OnePlus not wanting to swallow their pride and acknowledge that they cannot do for the OP2 what CM did for the OPO and for as much of a douche as Kurt McMaster is, he's not wrong in asserting that the OPO's success was built on the back of Cyanogen. OnePlus was not the reason for the One's meteoric success, the development community was and if 1+ continues to work against that community it will be the reason that not only the OP2 but the company as a whole fails. They had their formula for success, people like us were drawn to the OPO because it appeared to be a device that truly embodied the spirit of what it means to be an Android user. As of late they haven't been doing much except for sh*tting all over that formula, and their customer base. Take one look at the state of the 1+ forums today, compared to what it used to be when OPO was in it's prime and the decay is self evident.

Remember hearing that with the advent of Marshmallow we would be able to implement OP2's fingerprint scanner in custom ROMs due to it's now native API, yeah.. about that.

As a happy owner of a x-rite ColorMunki, I've managed to find the time to run some tests on the phone screen and find a suitable configuration for Boeffla Kernel's color settings.
First, some values for the un-calibrated display, with the default configuration (rgb 255, saturation 255, hue 0, display value 255, contrast 255) and maximum brightness:Black level = 0.2751 cd/m^2
50% level = 122.72 cd/m^2
White level = 578.07 cd/m^2 (quite close to the 600 cd/m^2 that OnePlus claims)
Approx. gamma = 2.24
Contrast ratio = 2101:1 (am I mistaken or OnePlus claimed "only" 1500:1??)
White chromaticity coordinates 0.2896, 0.3019
White Correlated Color Temperature = 8532K
Gamut coverage: 90.1% sRGB (not great)... http : // imgur. com /wb8kylH ... sorry but I can't post proper links yet.
Extremely "cold" color setting, with a quite remarkable contrast ratio and decent brightness. I'm quite impressed by this display!

To achieve a D65 (6500K) whitepoint and 2.2 gamma, as per sRGB standards, I've used the following settings:red: 255
green: 233
blue: 159
saturation: 255
hue: 0
display value: 260 (it basically affects the gamma)
contrast: 255
resulting in:Black level = 0.2804 cd/m^2 (shouldn't change)
50% level = 122.72 cd/m^2 (dictated by the gamma)
White level = 517.92 cd/m^2 (lost some brightness, unavoidable)
Approx. gamma = 2.19 (much closer to 2.2)
Contrast ratio = 1847:1 (I can live with that!)
White chromaticity coordinates 0.3121, 0.3288
White Correlated Color Temperature = 6540K

In my opinion, increasing the saturation above 255 is counter-productive, as it will only result in clipping. Furthermore, the vast majority of media content (unless you're working with professional Adobe RGB-based workflows) has most likely been designed for sRGB devices - or at least something with comparable gamut coverage. AMOLEDs are exceptional in terms of "color richness", but might result - if not properly calibrated - in unrealistic over-saturated colors.
The side-effect of these settings is the appearance of banding in images with blue gradients, such as... blue skies. I'm afraid, though, that this can't be solved in any way.

Cheers

threads.text: This is going to be an area I will be paying close attention to, I spend a lot of time in remote areas so I will be keeping my old faithful s5 in my vehicle just in case it doesn't perform like I hope it will

I used to have an iPhone 6 and I am weekly in an area where I can only get one bar with LTE. With nothing going on I regularly stream movies/anime. I have since went from the iPhone to zenfone 2,  I could get a signal but only 4g and barely. So I returned it and I've now had the OP2 for a few months and at first it will pick the(stronger but not faster) 4g connection but by manually changing to "LTE only"  in the hidden menu I get the same connection as the iPhone. Just need to change it back when done or else no phone calls. 

Overall it's satisfactory as I am able to do what I want to do, would just be nice not to go through the extra hoops to do so.

For a phone I was quite worried about it's doing well so far, usually in my living room I'm at 1 bar LTE signal, the OPT is sitting on 3 bars. 
Will still need to see how it performs in remote areas.
